awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: High-Strain-Rate Dynamics of Copolymer Microparticles for Advanced Additive Manufacturing
awd_abstract_narration:
In the cold particle gas spray manufacturing technique, sub- or super-sonic spraying of feedstock powders or micro-size polymeric particles can enable unique additive processing without the use of volatile organic compounds due to the extreme deformation of the microparticles during the collisions onto a substrate. As the consolidation occurs below the microparticles' melting temperature, extraordinary nanostructures created by the collision-induced deformation can remain and contribute to the performance of the end products. Thus, advanced additive manufacturing with the capability of nanoscale engineering of materials being deposited can be envisioned. Multiphase copolymers can serve as a promising material platform as they exhibit favorable inherent material behavior for cold particle gas spray process. This project intends to provide comprehensive and fundamental knowledge of the nanoscale morphologies of copolymers created under such process using an integrated experimental-computational approach. It is envisioned that a deeper understanding of high-strain-rate behavior of multiphase polymers will not only facilitate the development of the cold particle gas spray manufacturing technique but will also advance knowledge of materials use in extreme environments for defense applications, thereby promoting the progress of science; advancing the national health, prosperity, and welfare; and securing the national defense. The educational and outreach plan in this project includes: curriculum updates, development of a new teaching model based on student-led group projects and videography, and introduction to science and engineering for high school students through a specialized class at a local school.

The objective of this work is to determine the high strain-rate dynamic characteristics of multiphase block copolymers consisting of mechanically distinctive (hard/glassy and soft/rubbery) polymer blocks, for eventual application in cold particle gas spray manufacturing. High-velocity collision experiments of single copolymer micro-particle will be performed to achieve this. Under precise collision conditions including particles? kinetic energy, angular momentum, and temperature, high-strain-rate rheology and various transitions in phase and morphology will be studied. The research team will also perform simulations based on the development of new constitutive models. Detailed high-strain-rate dynamics of deformation and the contributions from nanoscale characteristics of the polymers to the manufacturing process will be quantitatively investigated. The successful completion of this project will establish a new microscopic methodology to understand high strain-rate characteristics of multiphase polymers. The data from this research will be made available in a publicly accessible database for wider dissemination.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
Cold spray (CS) additive manufacturing method can create products with less material and pollution by utilizing the most extreme mechanical consolidation process based on supersonic collisions of individual solid feedstock powders on a stationary surface. When polymeric feedstock powders are used in CS, their mechanical behaviors are inherently challenging to understand due to the nature of their collision-induced plastic deformation lasting shorter than one millionth seconds and resultant temperature rise changing the polymer?s original properties. Despite the challenges, since the consolidation can be achieved through very localized melting, limited to the collision surface of individual powders, the newly created nanoscale properties from the extreme collision event are preserved and affect the performance of the final products. In other words, CS can be envisioned as an additive manufacturing method enabling nanoscale-engineered materials through the extreme plastic deformation of the feedstock powers.

This collaborative NSF project investigated the mechanical properties of individual polymer particles that can be feedstock powders in CS. In this study, we specifically focus on copolymers consisting of soft and hard constituents. A laser pulse energy accelerated individual copolymer particles of different ratios of the soft and hard constituents, and their collision events were precisely observed with ultrafast stroboscopic microscopy. Through the particle?s collisions with a 45-degree inclined surface (Fig. 1), for the first time, the dynamic friction between the supersonically moving particles and the surface was measured using the momentum changes along the tangential and normal directions in a range of collision velocities up to Mach 2. The interfacial friction tended to increase more sensitively to the collision speed when increasing the volume fraction of the soft polymer constituent. Due to the heat generation at the interface, the polymer at the collision face becomes fluidic, and a rapid reduction of the interfacial friction occurs. The observed nonmonotonic evolution of the interfacial friction shed light on the tribological phenomenon existing for the extremely brief period of the mechanical contact. 

Furthermore, the copolymer particles were investigated under the 90-degree collision conditions resembling the actual CS consolidation process. Accurate adhesion conditions of the particles depending on their composition of the soft and hard constituents were quantified. The critical velocities for the onset of the particle adhesion to the substrate were precisely predicted by the tribological properties quantified from the angled collisions. Thus, the direct correlation between friction and adhesion mechanisms was confirmed under the ultrahigh strain rates. The impact-driven shear flows induced long-range structural ordering of nanostructures of the copolymers (Fig. 2) while generating adiabatic temperature rise beyond their glass transition temperatures. The collision-induced localized thermal response of the copolymer particles was computed through numerical modeling (performed by the Northeastern collaboration partner), in which the collision experiments calibrated modeling material parameters.

The most significant outcome of this work is the demonstration of an investigation platform for complex ultrahigh strain rate behaviors of copolymers through the data exchange between the single particle experiment and simulation. As depicted in Fig. 3, copolymers? empirical properties under extremely dynamic circumstances were quantified via controlled single-particle experiments. The Northeastern modeling collaboration group used the experimental results for their new cohesive and plasticity models for the copolymers under ultrahigh strain rates. As a result, the numerical simulations based on the developed model predicted the physical properties such as pressure, temperature, and strain rates, which were not attainable in the single particle experiment. Our collaborative project suggested a very reliable and accurate investigation method to the mechanical and materials research communities for the development of the future additive manufacturing technique.

 One female Ph.D. student was trained on a complete set of experimental techniques, including ultrasonic spray drying (sample fabrication), laser-induced projectile impact testing (collision experiment), and focused and diffuse ion beam (analysis). She won several prizes through presentations at professional conferences and trained as an independent researcher to perform her own research projects. She is now extending her expertise in a metal-based cold spray project sponsored by U.S. Army Research Lab.


Last Modified: 12/14/2022
Modified by: Jae-Hwang Lee
